intro: Phlegmariurus samoanus, commonly known as the Samoan clubmoss, is a species of vascular plant belonging to the family Lycopodiaceae. It is a small, evergreen plant that typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as forest floors or rocky crevices. The plant has a creeping habit, with stolons that root at the nodes and produce erect, spore-bearing shoots. Its leaves are linear and often arranged in whorls, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This species is native to the islands of Samoa and is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
